name.namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.abstract: In recent years, 20 states enacted a combined 36 policies that limit how and where protests can take place. This project investigates why some states choose to adopt anti-protest legislation while others do not. Understanding anti-protest policies is important to scholars at the intersection of state politics, public policy, and social movements. I employ multiple quantitative techniques throughout the dissertation including a survey experiment, event history analysis, and multilevel modeling, to analyze how individuals, states, and legislators react to protest activity, respectively. The survey experiment in chapter 2 tests how protest characteristics, including the group protesting and the tactics used by the protesters (peaceful, property damage, violence), influence individuals' attitudes toward anti-protest legislation. The results suggest that the type of group protesting does not affect attitudes toward anti-protest legislation, but the tactics used by the group are impactful. This suggests political tolerance for freedom of speech and freedom of assembly, even for protest groups with larger oppositions. In chapter 3, I use event history analysis to test the explanations of why states adopt anti-protest legislation, focusing on protest and political characteristics in each state. I find that protest activity in a state discourages anti-protest legislation. Instead, political variables--such as state partisan control--motivate the adoption of anti-protest legislation. I conclude that anti-protest legislation is politically motivated rather than necessary to curb rampant protest activity. Finally, in chapter 4, I use a multilevel model to test the explanations of why individual state legislators vote in favor of anti-protest legislation. I hypothesize that district, legislator, and state characteristics influence individual legislator roll call votes. The results of these analyses corroborate the event history analyses results--legislator partisanship explains most legislator voting. Taken together, this dissertation suggests that states adopt anti-protest legislation for politically motivated reasons rather than in response to local protest activity. Additionally, state and local protest activity discourages anti-protest legislation because legislators do not want to repress a politically active portion of the electorate. This study also illustrates the benefits of aggregating data at different levels (district and state) when discussing the adoption of policies.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Political Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Anti-Protest Laws, Policy Adoption, Protests, Roll Call Votes, State Politics, Survey Experiment
Eric Coleman, Professor Directing Dissertation; Deana Rohlinger, University Representative; William Berry, Committee Member; Michelle Whyman, Committee Member; Richard Fording, Committee Member.
